0	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-ross-idUSKCN10F2AT	Investor Wilbur Ross urges Trump not to let his behavior become the issue	"
By Jennifer Ablan
| NEW YORK

NEW YORK Billionaire investor Wilbur Ross stood behind Republican Donald Trump but urged him to stop engaging in exchanges that benefit the Democrats and make the real estate mogul's behavior the issue in the U.S. presidential campaign. ""This election is Donald's to lose and so far the Democrats have been clever about baiting him and he generally has bitten
column2: Ross said in an email to Reuters late on Wednesday.Ross said Trump's reaction in recent days to criticism by the parents of a Muslim U.S. Army captain killed in the Iraq war ""has enabled the Democrats to turn the table and instead of the behavior of the quintessential Washington insider being the issue he is in danger of letting the Democrats make his behavior be the issue.""

column1: Ross added
column2: ""I assume this will change soon.""A spokeswoman for Trump did not respond to requests for comment.

column1: Ross
column2: who has made billions of dollars betting on bankruptcies and distressed assets
column3: is a critic of Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton's trade views.The comments by Ross are the latest by Republican politicians and supporters expressing concern over the Trump campaign ahead of the Nov. 8 election against Clinton. Groups of wealthy Republicans unhappy with Trump have been privately courting prominent peers to join them in backing Clinton.

column1: Meg Whitman
column2: a prominent Republican fundraiser
column3: endorsed Clinton on Tuesday. (Reporting by Jennifer Ablan; Editing by Carmel Crimmins and Will Dunham)"

column1: 1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-iran-installment-idUSKCN10E264	Obama administration denies Iran cash payment was a ransom	"
By Lesley Wroughton
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON The Obama administration said on Wednesday that $400 million in cash paid to Iran soon after the release of five Americans detained by Tehran was not ransom as some Republicans have charged.The five
column2: including Washington Post reporter Jason Rezaian
column3: were released on Jan. 16 in exchange for seven Iranians held in the United States for sanctions violations. The prisoner deal coincided with the lifting of international sanctions against Tehran.At the time
column4: the United States said it had settled a longstanding Iranian claim at the Iran-U.S. Claims Tribunal in The Hague
column5: releasing $400 million in funds frozen since 1981
column6: plus $1.3 billion in interest that was owed to Iran.The funds were part of a trust fund Iran used before its 1979 Islamic Revolution to buy U.S. military equipment that was tied up for decades in litigation at the tribunal.Representative Jason Chaffetz
column7: chairman of the House of Representatives Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
column8: on Wednesday sent a letter to Secretary of State John Kerry asking him to appear at a future committee hearing to discuss the payment. White House spokesman Josh Earnest rejected suggestions the money transfer to Iran was ransom or a secret.    ""The United States
column10: has not paid a ransom to secure the release of Americans unjustly detained in Iran and we're not going to pay a ransom
column11: he said in response to a Wall Street Journal article that said Washington secretly organized the cash airlift.    Earnest said Republicans
column12: who have long opposed the Iran nuclear deal
column13: are seizing on how the money was paid to Iran as a way to undermine the deal. ""They're struggling to justify their opposition to our engagement with Iran

column1: While there have long been questions about the timing of the payment
column2: one Iranian concern was that the Obama administration could face too much domestic political criticism if it delayed acting on the tribunal's decision.Due to international sanctions against Iran
column3: the payment
column4: made in euros
column5: Swiss francs and other currencies
column6: had to be made in cash
column7: U.S. officials argue.One U.S. official said the $1.3 billion in interest was paid to Iran through the U.S. Treasury-administered Judgment Fund
column8: which is used to pay awards against the United States.Senior officials at the Justice Department had objected to sending cash on a plane to Iran at the same time that Iran was releasing four imprisoned Americans (the fifth American was released separately) but were overruled by the State Department
column9: The Wall Street Journal reported in a separate story on Wednesday
column10: citing people familiar with the discussions.

column1: People knew what it was going to look like
column2: and there was concern the Iranians probably did consider it a ransom payment
column3: the newspaper quoted one of the people as saying.Justice Department prosecutors were also concerned that the United States would release too many Iranian convicts and drop too many pending criminal cases against people suspected of violating sanctions laws
column4: the second Wall Street Journal report said.Reuters was unable to independently verify the report.In response to the report
column5: a Department of Justice spokesman said in a statement: ""The Department of Justice fully supported the ultimate outcome of the Administration's resolution of several issues with Iran
column7: as well as the return of U.S. citizens detained in Iran. We will not comment further on internal interagency deliberations.""

column1: A senior State Department official also responded by saying that the payment had been fully an interagency decision and that any idea that the State Department had the power to overrule was false.Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump blamed his Democratic opponent
column2: Hillary Clinton
column3: who was secretary of state during Obama's first term
column4: for launching the talks with Iran.""Our incompetent Secretary of State
column5: Hillary Clinton
column6: was the one who started talks to give 400 million dollars
column8: to Iran. Scandal!"" Trump said in a Twitter post.The chairman of the Republican National Committee
column10: also weighed in. ""The Obama-Clinton foreign policy not only means cutting a dangerous nuclear deal with the world's number one state sponsor of terrorism
column11: it also means paying them a secret ransom with cargo planes full of cash
column12: he said.House Speaker Paul Ryan was more measured
column15: this report confirms our longstanding suspicion that the administration paid a ransom in exchange for Americans unjustly detained in Iran."" (Additional reporting by Doina Chiacu
column17: Patricia Zengerle and Julia Harte; Editing by John Walcott and Leslie Adler)"

column1: 2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-idUSKCN10E1GL	Fury at top of Republican Party over Trump snub of House speaker	"
By Steve Holland and Emily Stephenson
| WASHINGTON/JACKSONVILLE
column2: Fla.

column1: WASHINGTON/JACKSONVILLE
column2: Fla. Donald Trump's White House campaign was in turmoil on Wednesday after he angered senior Republican Party leaders by criticizing a dead soldier's family and refusing to back the re-election campaign of House of Representatives Speaker Paul Ryan.On Tuesday
column3: Trump denied support to both Ryan and Senator John McCain in their coming primary contests
column4: hitting back at critics in the Republican leadership who have taken him to task for his insistent public dispute with the parents of the soldier
column5: a Muslim U.S. Army captain killed in the Iraq war. Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus was furious over the failure to endorse Ryan
column6: who is the most senior elected Republican
column7: and over Trump's feud with the Khan family
column8: two Republican sources said.""He feels like a fool
column9: a Republican source familiar with the situation said of Priebus.The RNC did not respond to a request for comment about Priebus. Another Republican source said Trump's family members
column10: who have played an influential role in his campaign
column11: were aware that an intervention was needed to get Trump back on track. One idea being floated was to have a senior adviser travel with Trump to help him stay on message.More than any other major figure in the Republican establishment
column12: Priebus worked to bring Trump into the party's fold despite the New York businessman's status as an outsider. Trump
column13: who had never previously run for public office
column14: beat 16 rivals to become the Republican presidential nominee for the Nov. 8 election.Ahead of last month's Republican Party Convention
column15: the RNC chairman sought to rally the fractured party behind Trump. Priebus feels burned by Trump's string of self-inflicted wounds and his refusal to observe basic decorum by giving Ryan his support.But in what appeared to be an effort to soothe ruffled feelings
column18: said on Wednesday he endorsed Ryan as ""a strong conservative leader"" and was doing so with Trump's blessing.The Indiana governor told Fox News that it takes time to build relationships in politics and that was exactly what Trump and Ryan were doing. Trump has had a running dispute with the parents of Army Captain Humayun Khan since they took the stage at last week's Democratic National Convention. Khizr Khan
column22: cited the sacrifice of their son
column23: who was killed by a car bomb in 2004
column24: and criticized Trump's proposal to combat terrorism by temporarily banning Muslims from entering the United States.

column1: Many Republican leaders
column2: including Ryan and McCain
column3: have criticized Trump's subsequent attacks on the parents. Even longtime ally Chris Christie
column4: the Republican New Jersey governor
column5: said it was inappropriate to attack the Khans.Trump's feud with the Khans was the final straw for Republican congressman Adam Kinzinger
column6: a former Air Force pilot and Iraq war veteran. Kinzinger
column7: who had held off supporting Trump
column8: told CNN on Wednesday: ""I just don't see how I get to Donald Trump anymore.""Trump
column9: who made his comments about Ryan and McCain in an interview with The Washington Post
column10: shrugged off the backlash.""There is great unity in my campaign
column11: perhaps greater than ever before. I want to thank everyone for your tremendous support. Beat Crooked H!"" he wrote on Twitter early on Wednesday
column13: Hillary Clinton.Campaign manager Paul Manafort told Fox News the campaign was moving in a positive direction
column14: with Trump himself in control. ""The campaign is in very good shape. We are organized. We are moving forward
column17: Trump said the news media's coverage of him was dishonest.

column1: We're doing quite well despite the fact that we get a totally false narrative
column2: he told supporters at a rally.At another campaign event in Florida
column3: in Jacksonville
column4: Trump pointed out a group of families
column5: known as Gold Star families
column6: who have lost loved ones in war
column7: calling them ""incredible people."" He didn't mention the spat with the Khans.RECENT TURMOIL

column1: Trump's always unruly campaign has been mired in disorder in recent days. On Monday
column2: Trump fired Ed Brookover
column3: a senior adviser hired as a liaison between the campaign and the RNC.

column1: Ryan
column2: who is favored to win next week in his race against primary challenger Paul Nehlen
column3: appeared to be trying to ignore the snub from Trump. An aide to the speaker said he would not have time to meet Trump later this week
column4: when Trump is expected to be campaigning in Wisconsin
column5: Ryan's home state.The aide did not indicate whether anyone had requested a get-together of Trump and Ryan
column6: but when asked whether they might meet to patch things up
column8: ""The speaker has a full schedule - can't back out of previous commitments in the (congressional) district.""A Republican congressional aide said there was deep frustration on Capitol Hill that Trump keeps engaging in ""petty spats."" The aide said congressional offices that support Trump got two sets of talking points on Monday from the campaign about the Khan situation but have not heard anything from the campaign about Trump's Ryan comments.The dissent over the Trump campaign also took other turns.Late on Tuesday
column10: a prominent Republican fundraiser and chief executive of Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE.N)
column12: calling Trump an ""authoritarian character"" and a threat to democracy.In better news for Trump
column13: his campaign and the RNC jointly raised $80 million for his White House bid in July
column14: the campaign said on Wednesday. That was less than the $90 million Clinton raised along with the national Democratic Party the same month
column15: but it was a substantial bump from past months.A former reality TV star
column16: Trump has won support particularly from white blue-collar workers who feel neglected by the political establishment. Along with his proposed ban on Muslims
column17: his plans have included building a wall along the Mexican border to keep out illegal immigrants and renegotiating trade agreements.Opinion polls have shown Clinton benefiting from a boost after her party's convention last week. The RealClearPolitics average of recent national polls put her 4.5 percentage points ahead of Trump
column18: at 46.5 percent to 42 percent.The Detroit Economic Club
column19: where candidates usually appear to give major economic addresses
column20: said Trump would speak at the club on Monday. (Additional reporting by Doina Chiacu
column21: David Alexander and Susan Cornwell; Writing by Frances Kerry; Editing by James Dalgleish and Leslie Adler)"

column1: 3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-poll-idUSKCN10D2GD	Clinton extends lead over Trump to 8 percentage points: Reuters/Ipsos	"
By Grant Smith
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton extended her lead over Republican rival Donald Trump to eight percentage points
column2: according to a Reuters/Ipsos poll released on Tuesday
column3: from six points on Friday.The bump for Clinton followed the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia last week at which Clinton and her supporters painted an optimistic portrait of America
column4: and came amid controversy over Trump's comments about the parents of a slain Muslim U.S. soldier.About 43 percent of likely voters favor Clinton
column5: 35 percent favor Trump
column7: according to the July 28-Aug. 1 online poll of 1
column8: 289 likely voters. The poll had a credibility interval of 3 percentage points.

column1: Trump has faced a barrage of criticism in recent days from political allies as well as opponents after he criticized the parents of U.S. Army Captain Humayun Khan
column2: who was killed in Iraq in 2004.The father
column3: Khizr Khan
column4: had harsh words for Trump at the Democratic convention where he spoke on Thursday night
column5: saying the 70-year-old businessman and former reality TV star had ""sacrificed nothing and no one"" and railing against his calls to ban Muslim immigrants.

column1: Trump responded saying Khan ""viciously attacked"" him
column2: and suggested the man was repeating lines fed to him by the Clinton campaign.New Jersey Governor Chris Christie
column3: who dropped out of the Republican presidential primary race and endorsed Trump
column4: said on Tuesday that Trump's criticisms of the Khans was ""inappropriate."" House Republican Richard Hanna of New York said it was ""not enough to simply denounce his (Trump's) comments
column5: and said he would support former Secretary of State Clinton instead.

column1: Trump had a short-lived bump in the polls after the Republican National Convention in Cleveland in late July
column2: when Reuters polling showed him slightly ahead of Clinton for the first time since May. (Editing by Richard Valdmanis)"

column1: 4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-justice-obama-idUSKCN10E25R	Obama cuts short prison sentences for 214 convicts	"
By Timothy Gardner
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON President Barack Obama cut short the prison terms of 214 convicts on Wednesday
column2: the largest number of commutations a U.S. leader has granted in single day since at least 1900
column3: the White House said.Obama has now granted a total of 562 commutations during his presidency
column4: more than the number by the past nine presidents combined
column5: it said. In Wednesday's batch
column6: 67 convicts were serving life sentences.The convicts were serving time for crimes including possession of crack cocaine and methamphetamine
column7: with intent to distribute. Some were imprisoned on charges of gun possession. One of the convicts
column10: was serving a 20 year sentence that began in 2006 for possession of crack with intent to distribute. He will be released in December.

column1: Obama has worked to reform the U.S. criminal justice system and reduce the number of people serving long sentences for nonviolent drug offences. It is a rare issue on which Obama gets support from Republican lawmakers.For years crack offenders faced stiffer penalties than powder cocaine offenders
column2: even though the substances are similar at the molecular level. Critics have said the disparity has unfairly harmed minority and poor communities.
Obama announced the most ambitious clemency program in 40 years
column3: inviting thousands of drug offenders and other convicts to seek early release. But the program has struggled under a flood of unprocessed cases. ""Our work is far from finished
column4: White House counsel Neil Eggleston said about the commutations. Eggleston urged Congress to take action. ""While we continue to work to act on as many clemency applications as possible
column5: only legislation can bring about lasting change to the federal system

column1: The program automatically expires when Obama leaves office next January and it is uncertain whether the next president would continue with a similar plan. Donald Trump
column2: the Republican candidate in the Nov. 8 election
column3: has championed ""law and order"" in his campaign. Democrat Hillary Clinton has called for criminal justice reform.  (Reporting by Timothy Gardner and Ayesha Rascoe; Editing by Andrew Hay and Steve Orlofsky)"

column1: 5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-ethanol-idUSKCN10E1P5	Clinton campaign studying alternative to U.S. ethanol mandate	"
By Valerie Volcovici and Rory Carroll
| WASHINGTON/SAN FRANCISCO

WASHINGTON/SAN FRANCISCO Democratic U.S. presidential candidate Hillary Clinton's campaign has solicited advice from California regulators on how to revamp a federal regulation requiring biofuels like corn-based ethanol be blended into the nation's gasoline supply
column2: according to campaign and state officials.    The move is the clearest sign yet that
column3: if elected
column4: Clinton would seek to adjust the regulation
column5: called the Renewable Fuel Standard
column6: possibly hurting her chances in corn-growing states like Iowa where she faces a tough battle against Republican rival Donald Trump in the Nov. 8 election.The Renewable Fuel Standard
column8: mandates that transportation fuel sold in the United States contain a minimum volume of renewable fuels.It was intended to cut greenhouse gas emissions and expand the U.S. renewable fuels sector while lowering reliance on imported oil. It is opposed by the oil industry and environmentalists and has been criticized as a mere subsidy to corn producers. Clinton advisers have contacted the California Air Resources Board (CARB) to discuss whether a policy like California's Low Carbon Fuel Standard
column9: a market-based system rather than a mandate
column10: could be applied at a national level to replace or augment the Renewable Fuel Standard
column14: said she discussed the state's regulations with Clinton advisers.While a backer of the Low Carbon Fuel Standard
column15: Nichols said she told Clinton's advisers they could avoid political backlash by focusing on other carbon-reduction strategies instead
column16: such as expanding electric vehicle sales and cleaning up emissions from coal-fired electricity.Nichols did not provide further details on the discussions.

column1: A Clinton campaign official
column2: who asked not to be named
column3: confirmed the discussions with CARB but gave no further details. A campaign spokesman
column4: Tyrone Gayle
column5: said the campaign has been seeking advice from ""a diverse set of stakeholders."" He added that the Clinton campaign ""does not support replacing the RFS with a national low-carbon fuel standard"" but did not elaborate.Former Obama administration climate and energy adviser Heather Zichal said on the sidelines of the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia last week that the Renewable Fuel Standard was broken
column6: but that a Clinton administration could make ""modifications"" to fix it.""Mandates aren't necessarily a perfect way to regulate

column1: The U.S. corn lobby hopes to convince both Clinton and Trump to uphold the regulation
column2: which requires a doubling of U.S. biofuels use to 36 billion gallons per year by 2022
column3: when congressionally mandated volume targets are set to expire. The program is designed to last indefinitely after that.Environmentalists
column4: anti-hunger activists and the oil sector have called for the rule to be repealed or changed because they say it raises food and fuel costs without delivering the emissions reductions that it was intended to achieve.MARKET-BASED SYSTEM

column1: The California regulation
column2: a key part of the state's effort to combat climate change
column3: requires a 10 percent reduction in the carbon intensity of transportation fuels by 2020
column4: but leaves it up to companies to decide how to reach that target.    California enacted the Low Carbon Fuel Standard in 2007 targeting oil refiners and distributors that sell in the state's market. It angered Midwestern ethanol interests because the regulation counts the carbon dioxide footprint of transporting biofuels into the state for blending
column5: effectively blocking many of those imports. Oil companies have complained that the regulation is costly.Clinton in May expressed support for the federal Renewable Fuel Standard in an opinion piece published in an Iowa newspaper
column6: but said it could be improved.Clinton's openness to overhauling the Renewable Fuel Standard appears to contrast with Trump's position. During the state-by-state battle for the Republican presidential nomination
column7: Trump said he supported the biofuel mandates set out in the Renewable Fuel Standard.Corn and ethanol industry lobbyists said they have been talking with both the Clinton and Trump campaigns to argue in favor of the Renewable Fuel Standard. (Additional reporting by Joe White in Detroit and Chris Prentice in New York; Editing by Will Dunham and Leslie Adler)"

column1: 6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-goldstar-muslim-idUSKCN10E1NS	Muslim families of fallen U.S. soldiers driven to oppose Trump	"
By Lucas Jackson and Barbara Goldberg
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK Nazar Naqvi has faithfully voted Republican for more than three decades. After Donald Trump's feud with Muslim parents who lost a son in battle for the United States
column2: he has vowed not a single Republican will get his vote.Naqvi
column4: a retired U.S. government engineer from Newburgh
column5: New York
column6: is a member of a small community of Muslims who are among America's Gold Star families
column7: those whose loved ones were killed while serving in the U.S. military. His son Mohsin Naqvi
column9: enlisted in the U.S. Army four days after Sept. 11
column11: and was killed in 2008 by a roadside bomb in Afghanistan.Trump lashed out at Khizr and Ghazala Khan
column12: the Pakistani American parents of slain U.S. Army Captain Humayun Khan
column13: after they appeared at last week's Democratic convention in Philadelphia to criticize the Republican presidential hopeful for proposing a temporary ban on Muslims entering the country. ""I'm going to vote for anyone but Republicans because of this one person
column14: this man who has gone out of his mind
column15: Naqvi said this week. ""Not any office should get our vote. He has been nominated not by one person - the Republican Party nominated him.""Naqvi said he was pressing his registered Republican friends to do the same.    The Pentagon says that 3
column16: 939 active duty service members have identified themselves as Muslim
column17: less than 1 percent of the 1.3 million active duty U.S. military troops
column18: but a Pentagon spokesman said there is no record of how many Muslims have been killed in action.

column1: Reuters reached out to a dozen Muslim Gold Star families who lost a loved one in action after Sept. 11
column2: 2001.The families are not organized as a group and some did not  want to talk. But those who did agreed that Trump's comments upended their political loyalties
column3: and moved them to take action to register and motivate other voters to keep Trump out of the White House in November.Nooshin Razani
column5: an Iranian-American pediatrician in Oakland
column7: whose 19-year-old brother Omead Razani died while serving as a U.S. Army medic in Iraq in 2004
column8: said Trump's comments sparked her to speak to the press for the first time.""When I saw there was this person who was willing to use religion in this negative way

column1: Trump rebuked Khizr Khan for suggesting that he should read the U.S. Constitution and said his wife Ghazala may have stood silently by her husband because she might not have been ""allowed"" to speak.Although Trump did call their son a hero and said his aim was to end radical Islamic terror
column2: the ensuing uproar has caused many Republicans to distance themselves from him and to support the Khan family.    Razani joined more than 20 Gold Star families in signing an open letter calling for Trump to apologize to the Khans and said she is going to volunteer to register voters
column3: mainly because of Trump's comments about Ghazala Khan
column4: which she said insulted all Muslim women.""I want to be an active part of making sure people's voices are heard. Even people Trump thinks don't speak up
column5: Razani said.

column1: Trump's ongoing dispute with the Khans has become a call to political action for Kevin Ahearn of Phoenix. His brother
column2: Army Major James Ahearn
column3: converted to Islam to marry a woman with whom he fell in love in Iraq
column4: brought to the United States and with whom he had a daughter before he was killed by a bomb in Iraq in 2007. Kevin Ahearn
column6: said on Tuesday that he and his husband planned to go to Democratic Headquarters in Phoenix to volunteer for the first time.""It makes me all the more determined that he does not make it to the White House
column8: whose Muslim niece now is 10.The soldier's mother said she was shocked by Trump's rhetoric and wishes she could talk to her late son about it.""He was always a staunch Republican because they backed the military. I can't imagine how he would feel now
column11: who lives in the San Francisco area. (Reporting by Lucas Jackson and Barbara Goldberg; Additional reporting by Emily Hubbard and Joseph Ax in New York; Editing by Toni Reinhold)"
